title: Levi P. Morton
added: Morton became ill during the winter of 1919 to 1920; a cold developed into bronchitis, and he eventually contracted pneumonia, which proved fatal.<ref>{{cite news |date=May 17, 1920 |title=Levi P. Morton is Dead on his 96th Birthday |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/64385651/ |work=The Sun and the New York Herald |location=New York, NY |page=1 |url-access=subscription }}</ref> He died in [[Rhinebeck, New York]], on May 16, 1920, his 96th birthday.<ref>{{cite news |title=Morton A Resident Of Washington. Only Part of His Estate Will Be Taxable in This State. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/05/18/118316212.pdf |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 18, 1920 |access-date=May 16, 2015 }}</ref> After a memorial service at the [[Cathedral of St. John the Divine]], he was interred at Rhinebeck Cemetery.<ref>{{cite news |date=May 18, 1920 |title=Many Notables to Attend Funeral of Levi P. Morton |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/114938646/|work=Poughkeepsie Eagle-News |location=Poughkeepsie, NY |page=1 |url-access=subscription }}</ref> At age 96, Morton is the [[List of vice presidents of the United States by age|second-longest living]] vice president; only [[John Nance Garner]], who died at age 98, lived longer.<ref>{{cite news |last=B. L. |date=September 22, 2002 |title=Vice presidential haunts |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2002-09-22-0209210020-story.html |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |location=Chicago, IL |access-date=May 14, 2020}}</ref>
